column7:
If you could choose, would you want to be assessed with a heavily weighed exam (80–100%) or with significant coursework components?
Please ignore project courses; this question is about which opti...
column8: Any optional comments?
column11: Cleaned Comments

column8: Puts so much stress on the final exam, when we are already working to the bone for the heavy coursework load throughout the year

column8: If coursework is heavy, exams shouldn’t be 40% pass as well

column8: I learn much more from coursework, as there is time to do deeper and extracurricular reading. Exams unnerve me and a lot of the time I perform very well in practice exams and very poorly in real ones.

column8: I feel coursework overall shows a better example of how you are doing throughout the term. I do not think you should get rid of exams but the stress on the one day I don’t feel is ever a good representation of how one person does overall so I think coursework should be weighted more as both are equally important
column11: feel coursework overall shows better example how throughout term not think should get rid exams stress on one day don’t feel ever good representation how one person overall so think coursework should weighted more both equally important

column8: Exams while in the moment are stressful, but during the actual course itself it makes it less stressful in my opinion. I think there should always be at least some course component in all courses however but only about 20% seems to be fair

column8: 70/80% exam is my personal preference with the rest being appropriate continous assessment

column8: Not a massive fan of 80% of a course relying on one exam, as I believe it is not a fair way of assessing one's knowledge of the courses. It also relies on luck, because sometimes the topic of a question might be easier for you and sometimes it might be really hard. I feel that more continuous assessment throughout the year would be a better measure of people's knowledge of the course.
column11: not massive fan 80 course relying on one exam believe not fair way assessing ones knowledge courses also relies on luck sometimes topic question might easier sometimes might really hard feel more continuous assessment throughout year would better measure peoples knowledge course

column8: Coursework allows for more of an understanding: in my experience, examination preparation tends to be more learning standard techniques by rote from notes and coursework is more about new applications of understanding
column11: coursework allows more understanding in experience examination preparation tends to more learning standard techniques rote from notes coursework more new applications understanding

column8: General coursework dependant modules I have taken I tend to perform much better on, I feel this is largely due to the fact that in coursework assessment you’re graded on your knowledge of the entirety of the course material. Examinations can only assess so much
column11: general coursework dependant modules taken tend to perform much better on feel largely due to fact in coursework assessment you’re graded on knowledge entirety course material examinations can only assess so much

column8: I find it overly stressful and unfair for hundreds of hours of work over an entire year to be assessed in 2 to 3 hours. It is much easier to underperform during an exam than overperform, so an average over an entire degree may be affected, especially when it is impossible to assess every aspect of a course during an exam. I also find coursework to incentivise better learning practices, as it requires keeping up with content as it is being taught.
column11: find overly stressful unfair hundreds hours work over entire year to assessed in 2 to 3 hours much easier to underperform during exam than overperform so average over entire degree may affected especially when impossible to assess every aspect course during exam also find coursework to incentivise better learning practices requires keeping up content taught

column8: More heavily weighted coursework such as in many of the School of Maths courses can often allow for better understanding of concepts throughout the semester and also stops grades being ruined by a poor performance during a 2 hour exam with 2 questions that does not allow you to fully demonstrate any knowledge that you may have.
column11: more heavily weighted coursework such in many school maths courses can often allow better understanding concepts throughout semester also stops grades ruined poor performance during 2 hour exam 2 questions not allow to fully demonstrate any knowledge may

column11: feel coursework helps learning reduces anxiety exam also

column11: exams give little bit more freedom to get better over semester means dont get totally snowed under find yourself crunch time something non course related

column8: Sometimes exams do not reflect the teaching and assessment style throughout the year and is so heavily dependant on the lecturer writing it (creates a disadvantage when our year has had several new lecturers over the past 2 years). Narrows the number of topics that can be assessed. If a topic that you aren’t great with comes up on coursework you have the time to work through the question and ultimately understand it more but if a topic you are less sure of comes up on an exam you do not have that chance and then your overall grade is incredibly negatively affected despite the fact you may have a deep understanding of all the other topics.
column11: sometimes exams not reflect teaching assessment style throughout year so heavily dependant on lecturer writing creates disadvantage when year several new lecturers over past 2 years narrows number topics can assessed topic aren’t great comes up on coursework time to work question ultimately understand more topic less sure comes up on exam not chance then overall grade incredibly negatively affected despite fact may deep understanding all other topics

column8: Coursework deadlines can be stressful when multiple are close to each other. Coursework does reduce impact of one bad day on final grade. Coursework can help build understanding over course of semester.

column8: While exams in theory mean more time for learning throughout the course, I’ve found my courses still have a lot of coursework but it’s just not worth a large percentage.
column11: exams in theory mean more time learning throughout course i’ve found courses still lot coursework it’s just not worth large percentage

column8: The best course I have had, in my opinion, with regards to assessment was ILA in first year. The beauty of that course's assessment was that it struck a good balance. I think having 100% exam is a poor decision. It feels unfair that a whole semester's work is judged off of an exam lasting 3 hours. But equally, if every course was fully coursework, then it could really addup. So as I say, like in ILA a 30-40 % exam and 60-70% coursework mark is the fairest form of assessment. It is folly to think that just because a course focusses on coursework throughout the semester that it affords less valuable learning. I think I learn better from course work than cramming for an exam. Coursework forces consistency. Exams encourage solely a good memory.
column11: best course in opinion regards to assessment ila in first year beauty courses assessment struck good balance think having 100 exam poor decision feels unfair whole semesters work judged off exam lasting 3 hours equally every course fully coursework then could really addup so say like in ila 3040 exam 6070 coursework mark fairest form assessment folly to think just course focusses on coursework throughout semester affords less valuable learning think learn better from course work than cramming exam coursework forces consistency exams encourage solely good memory

column8: I’d prefer a fair split, 70 exam 30 coursework minimum. 100% exam is ridiculous

column8: Coursework only assestement just means you put in time, but does not necessarily reflect actual knowledge. Exams with self made synopsis are best of both worlds I think. Also, with increasingly advanced AI, I am sceptical of people not cheating, however much the uni policies instruct not to. In physics especially, I think coursework heavy subjects are detrimental to the level of education and worth of my degree. For coding and independent research subjects it does make sense, but for something like math or physics there is no easy way to test without stress, stress should not be religiously avoided. If you want to make exams less stressful, I think it would be much better just to give self made synopsis and more time than necessarily needed. Feel free to contact me for more feedback.

column8: Hand-ins with maths and physics exercises might be even more useful sometimes to practice the concepts you’ve learned. Hand-ins shouldn’t be too long then though, because especially from JH onwards the amount of courses and their difficulty increases considerably, and the student might feel overwhelmed if there’s too many problems in a single hand-in and has to do several of them.

column8: I feel like having a more even split of coursework and exam reduces variance and leads to a more accurate measure of the student's understanding because when the almost entire course mark depends on the performance in just one day it means that random factors on that day (having a headache or minor illness, poor sleep, test anxiety) that are out of control of the student can have a large influence on the overall mark in the course. Furthermore, having more emphasis on the coursework means that the student is continually assessed throughout the semester, as compared to exams that a student could cram for, which might increase their mark in the exam but not represent knowledge they would carry over well in the future.
column11: feel like having more even split coursework exam reduces variance leads to more accurate measure students understanding when almost entire course mark depends on performance in just one day means random factors on day having headache minor illness poor sleep test anxiety out control student can large influence on overall mark in course furthermore having more emphasis on coursework means student continually assessed throughout semester compared to exams student could cram might increase their mark in exam not represent knowledge would carry over well in future

column8: I answered; “heavily weighted exam”. My reflection is that if there is a 40% pass component for exams then the increase coursework component takes time away from studying for the exam. I think that coursework is more representative of the real world, during which time can be taken to think about a problem and workload can be managed. Exams are more highly pressured and more time should be given.

column8: Having too much emphasis on one final exam adds unnecessary stress. One bad afternoon and it wipes out a semester worth of hard work. Personally I'd much prefer putting less weight on the exam, and adding more continuous assessment throughout the semester. For example maybe making hand-ins more frequent, or increasing the importance of the mid term test. Thanks.

column8: Constant coursework makes it hard to schedule. Not everyone has the same energy levels and resources each week, and exams allow more flexibility in managing resources, illness, other commitments, etc. I also preferred the old exams with a choice in questions, it means if I really focus down on parts of the content and don't manage to cover others well then I have a better opportunity to demonstrate understanding. Ultimately you can't do it all and both coursework and 100% required questions make for much more constant stress at the expense of really learning the course content..

column8: In recent time, the exams for my course have changed from being able to choose which questions to answer, to now being only given certain ones to do. This is the reason I suspect why we are seeing lower exam results (See the feedback forms). As an example, the recent Dynamics and Vector Calculus exam had exceptionally poor results, and an entire section of the course (changing coordinate systems) did not even have a single question, instead the majority of marks being delegated to 3d integration questions. A large chunk of the dynamics course was also not examined for the same reason. This problem was made significantly worse by the fact we were not allowed a self-made sheet. As for why I do not believe coursework should be the majority of the grade, I am almost certain that the majority of students partially cheat these handins and quizzes. You would see insane grade inflation. It would also increase stress levels as every handin would be even more important. Most importantly, students would also feel cheated if they did very well in an exam of the same length as before but is instead weighted very little in such a new coursework dependent system.
column11: in recent time exams course changed from able to choose questions to answer to now only given certain ones to reason suspect why seeing lower exam results see feedback forms example recent dynamics vector calculus exam exceptionally poor results entire section course changing coordinate systems not even single question instead majority marks delegated to 3d integration questions large chunk dynamics course also not examined same reason problem made significantly worse fact not allowed selfmade sheet why not believe coursework should majority grade almost certain majority students partially cheat handins quizzes would see insane grade inflation would also increase stress levels every handin would even more important most importantly students would also feel cheated very well in exam same length before instead weighted very little in such new coursework dependent system

column8: Coursework works best when feedback is available immediately, I have had experience with a course that was able to provide almost immediate and surprisingly good feedback for it's online maths quizzes and it helped me improve so much faster than the alternative. The name fo the course was Fundementals of Algebra and Calculus if that's helpful at all.

column8: I have found for courses on key physics topics, such as quantum or thermal, that 80% exam works best. The coursework means throughout the semester you get feedback on exam style questions which is valuable; and I think a heavily weighted exam is the best way to test the knowledge. For courses more based on maths, such as MoMP and Fourier analysis and stats, more coursework would be better. This is as the maths takes longer to sink in, and a lot of people by exams aren't confident in answering the questions in the allotted time without making mistakes etc. But in their own time can answer them confidently and have understood the material. Maybe a 60(exam)/40 split or something similar would be a more fair way of assessing students in such courses. I still feel they should be weighted more towards exams as I believe they are the a good/best way of assessing someones understandings in both maths and physics.
column11: found courses on key physics topics such quantum thermal 80 exam works best coursework means throughout semester get feedback on exam style questions valuable think heavily weighted exam best way to test knowledge courses more based on maths such momp fourier analysis stats more coursework would better maths takes longer to sink in lot people exams arent confident in answering questions in allotted time without making mistakes etc in their own time can answer confidently understood material maybe 60exam40 split something similar would more fair way assessing students in such courses still feel should weighted more towards exams believe goodbest way assessing someones understandings in both maths physics
